patient_information: Age: 31 years Sex: male Country of origin: Guatemala Immigration history: immigrated to New York City 5 years ago Past medical history: no past medical history Vaccinations: unknown Allergies: unknown Travel history: recent travel to Guatemala Occupation: unknown
chief_complaint: Symptoms: acute weakness and numbness of the leg Duration: several minutes before arrival at hospital
history_of_present_illness: Onset: transitory ischemic attack (TIA) several minutes before arrival at hospital Progression: symptoms resolved just before his arrival at the hospital Other symptoms: two episodes of facial twitching two weeks prior that subsided without intervention after 10 seconds
exposure_and_epidemiology: Travel history: recent travel to Guatemala Vector exposures: unknown Animal exposures: unknown Water food risks: unknown Contacts: unknown Season outbreak context: unknown
vitals: Temperature: normal Blood pressure: normal Heart rate: normal Respiratory rate: normal Oxygen saturation: normal
physical_exam: Cranial nerves: intact Motor sensory examinations: normal Deep tendon reflexes: normal Gait: normal Rest of exam unremarkable: true
labs_and_diagnostics: Cell blood count serum chemistry: within normal limits Imaging results: [{"type": "CT angiography", "description": "showed patent cerebral arteries"}, {"type": "MRI", "description": "revealed parenchymal calcified lesions, complex cystic structures in the subarachnoid space and an old lacunar infarct proximal to a cyst with a normal CT angiography"}]
differential_diagnosis: Considered: ["subarachnoid neurocysticercosis", "other causes of subarachnoid space lesions"] Evidence for subarachnoid neurocysticercosis: ["parenchymal calcified lesions", "complex cystic structures in the subarachnoid space", "old lacunar infarct proximal to a cyst with normal CT angiography"] Evidence against subarachnoid neurocysticercosis: ["normal CT angiography"]
management_and_clinical_course: Treatment: [{"type": "high dose of prednisone followed by a taper", "description": "and dual therapy with albendazole and praziquantel"}] Clinical response: serum cysticercosis antigen was positive at the beginning of therapy. A spine MRI did not show evidence of spinal involvement. Outcome: after 9 months of treatment, his serum antigen was negative and his lesions resolved on imaging.
final_diagnosis: Disease name short: Subarachnoid neurocysticercosis Confirmation method: serum cysticercosis antigen run at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) was positive. Evidence for subarachnoid neurocysticercosis: ["parenchymal calcified lesions", "complex cystic structures in the subarachnoid space", "old lacunar infarct proximal to a cyst with normal CT angiography"] Evidence against subarachnoid neurocysticercosis: ["normal CT angiography"]
